The aathor's first method is the generally accepted 6nel', the second consists in passing to rectilinear motion L%s a lim-it.of: mo Lion along a conical section. S/124/63/000/001/036/080 D234/ '. 308 Janiczek, Roman_ TITLE: The significance of the Love and Flamant - Boussinesq problems in the method of sections PERIODICAL: lZcferativnyy zhurnal, Nekhanika, no. 1, 1963, 5, abstract 1V27 (Zesz. naW.I. Politechn. czestochow. 1960, no. 11, 3-20 (11ol. : sum. aries in Rus. and ""ng.)) T The author considers the possibility of using the method of sections for solving two-dimensional problems of the theory of elasticity. Une can start with the solution for a plane loaded by a concentrated force at an arbitrary-point (Love's problem) or by the solution for a half-plane loaded at an arbitrary point of* its edge by an inclined concentrated force (1.71amant - 2oussinesq problem). Different methods of solution can be very complicated in individual cases and the use of electronic computers is therefore recorwended. The author proposes the follo~Ang formulation of the problem; a disc of an arbitrary outline, with arbitrary load, is considered as a Card V2 ~/124/63/000/001/036/080 The significance of the LoVC ... The disc is taken as an unbounded quart'er-plane, assumed to be a space common to two unbounded half-planes, whose edgee. aro perpendicular to each other. Since the symmetry rule can be applied! to-such a case, the iterative operations are much simplified. It 1s sho~.rn that, although the iteration series are fai;t converging, thd results even in this simple case can be obtained only by meaw of tedious computation of several tablea. The results obtained are .1 approximate, the accuracy depending on the common ratio Ic assumedi for length division. The T)-~IICISQ,Ures developed are partimila-rly Suited for 5,31~jc-.5 Authors, sujLrvrv. 435h2 s/196/62/UOO/022/oo6/007 E194/E155 AUTHOR: Janiczek, Stefan TlTLE: A high output, high voltage unipolar d.c. machine PER10DICAL: Referativnyy zhurnal, ElektrotQkhnika i energetika, no.22, 1962, 5, abstract 22 1 25 P. (Pol. patent, c1. 2ldl, 6, no.44923, September 21, 1961) TEXT: A special feature of the machine patented is that it is cooled by compressed helium or simil'ar gas flowing in hollow cdnductors forming the windinga. The machine operateo in a vacuum chamber made of material of low thermal coriductivitv. The bearings do not require lubrication at low temperatures. The magnetic circuit of the machine is made of an alloy of zinc and zirconium. The active conductors are made of an alloy of molybdenum or hafnium. The electrical reliability of the machine is high, it is of relatively simple construction, small size and weight per unit output. The machines patented may be used as generators, or motors of high output at high voltage in long- distance d.c. power transmission. Inst Title The Polyvinyl Chloride Coatings in Wine Making Industry. Orig Pub Kvaany prumysl, 1958) 4, no 4, 81-83- Abstract The polyvinyl chloride coatings are not suitable for re- servoirs because they effect the flavor and taste of wine. The coatings from an epoxy resin Upon 1200 P might be used for a short lasting storage of ordinary wines, shercupon a constant quality control and iron content of the wine being stored is essential. The changes in the,level of lactic acidin ECT and conditioning BRATISLAVSKE LEKARS.LISTY 1956, 36/2 (80-87) Graphs 3 Tables 2 In 26 psychotics and 6 dogs observations were made on the blood lactic acid level in the following situations: (1) before ECT and in various Intervals after It; (2) si. milarly before and after a situation up to details equal to that of ECT b,)t without letting electric current be passed through the head. The foltowing conclusions are made: Blood lactic acid level after ECT equals that during hard physical labour. The course of changes is biphasic. Once ECT is repeated, conditioned elevations of pre-ECT level are observed. Chanjes after -a pretended ECT-situation are ii. milar to those after ECT, supposing the person or animal got a real ECT at le"' once before, An extinction of these conditioned hurnoral changes was observed vhftl repeating the pretended ECT-situation after 20 days. gkoda - PestrA EXCERPTA MMIGA Sac.z vol.9/n FbrAology,ete. Nov56 5211. J&L(K . and RUSCAK M. Psychiat. Klin. LFUK a Fyziol.. fJst. LFUK. - __ A~ Bratislava. *Prfspevok k otdzke podmienenych reflexov na inzulrn. Contri- bution to the question of conditioned reflexes to insulin BRATISLAVSKt LEKARS..LISTY 1956, 3613 (160-168) Graphs 7 In 27 mental patients treated with insulin shocks, blood sugar curves were stu- died under various conditions. After repetition of shocks, subthreshold insulin doses were found to provoke shocks accompanied by marked hypoglyeaemin. In such corditions, even after sham injection of saline. hypoglycaemin of the same value as that during normal insulin shock was found, although tio shock occurred. That is explained as a conditioned reflex phenomenon. Such 'conditioned hypogly- caemic curves' may be of complicated shape (initial hyperglyeaemia or double de- pression of blood sugar level). Repeated treatment with reduced insulin doses, however. brought about extinction of the conditioned reaction. Holubar - Prague SLOVAKIA / Human and Animal Physiology. Metabolism. Leka. Listy, 1957, 1, No 11, 647-661. Abstract: The content of lactic aoid (L) sugar, and uric acid was determined in the blood in 71 pationta with acute psychoses. Tho content of L in acute psychoses was elevated; in depressive states it was lowered, in patients without ps~po; chomotor changes it was somewhat higher, and still higher in patients in agitated states.
